thread.title: Market ends volatile week with a fall
thread.title_full: Market ends volatile week with a fall

title: Market ends volatile week with a fall
text:
Fri, Aug 14, 2015, 6:08 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed Market ends volatile week with a fall AAP â€“ 42 minutes ago Print 
The share market ended a volatile week with a fall due to weak commodity prices and subdued reaction to mixed company profit reports. 
Phillip Capital senior client adviser Michael Heffernan said the market has been underwhelmed by what he described as a solid week for company earnings. 
Telstra, Commonwealth Bank and CSL were among the biggest companies to release results. 
"We have had some pretty good results this week but unless they have been spectacular the share prices of good stocks are marked down," Mr Heffernan said. 
"There haven't been any major stocks moving upwards to give a bit of life to the market today." 
The main indices dropped more than 0.5 per cent on Friday, the third session of falls in a week also dominated by China's currency valuations. 
Recent declines in the iron ore price and speculation of further devaluations of the Chinese currency dented mining stocks. 
BHP Billiton shed 19 cents to $25.32, Rio Tinto dropped 83 cents to $51.13 and Fortescue Metals lost 3.5 cents to $1.785. 
Atlas Iron held its ground at 3.1 cents despite posting a $1.4 billion annual loss due to massive falls in the price of iron ore. 
The energy sector suffered the heaviest losses after oil prices fell to a fresh six-year low on rekindled fears of an oil glut. 
Woodside Petroleum dropped $1.21 to $32.84, Santos shed 59 cents to $5.99 and Oil Search was 22 cents lower at $6.70. 
The banks also dropped, with NAB down 22 cents at $31.76, ANZ down 47 cents at $29.29 and Westpac was 47 cents lower at $31.33. 
CBA remains in a trading halt following its announcement of a $5 billion capital raising. 
Among the better performers was Automotive Holdings which posted a 21 per cent lift in full year profit due to contributions from new acquisitions. 
Its shares rose 17 cents, or 4.1 per cent, to $4.31. 
KEY FACTS 
* At the close on Friday, the benchmark S&P/ASX200 index was down 31.4 points, or 0.58 per cent, at 5,356.5 points. 
* The broader All Ordinaries index was down 29 points, or 0.54 per cent, at 5,360 points. 
* The September share price index futures contract was 37 points lower at 5,280, with 25,679 contracts traded. 
* The price of gold in Sydney at 1700 AEST was $US1,116.50 per fine ounce, down $US4.40 on Thursday's price of $US1,120.90. 
* National turnover was 2.35 billion securities worth $5.08 billion. @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook
